history.content:
EE126 covers almost all of Stat 134 in the first month-and-a-half and then covers estimation methods (maximum likelihood, MAP) as well as a brief overview of Bayesian vs. frequentist interpretations of statistics. Additionally, joint gaussians - which are the essential noise model you will study in 189 - are a big component in the latter half of 126. Also covered (but not as relevant to 189) are discrete and continuous-time Markov chains, Bernoulli processes, Poisson processes (these 2 in particular really help unify your conception of the different probability distributions from CS70), and Markov decision processes, which are relevant to CS188. 

Something rarely mentioned is the lab portion of 126. I found that this helped to really solidify the concepts in my head, especially for concepts like the Viterbi algorithm and the Kalman filter that are much harder to explain through formulas but trivial to understand as code. If you are a CS student, I highly recommend EE126.

Stat 134 mainly focuses on continuous probability - random variables, expectation, covariance, some common distributions like the multivariate gaussian. Since (like CS70) most students take it as their first probability course, it probably won't be as useful for you.

Stat 140 is more similar to Stat 134 but intended to be better preparation for CS189, so it has added content including more Markov Chains, Markov Chain Monte Carlo. Like EE126, it relates some distributions you have learned, such as the Poisson as the limit of the Binomial, the Central Limit Theorem, etc.

The single best choice for students in EECS, CS, EIS, etc... is EECS 126. This is also the best prep for 189. 

The faculty in EECS and Stat both agree about this, because 126 can lean on 70 and the programming experience that folks in the department have. If for whatever reason 126 is not available to you, then Stat 140 is the next best choice. 134 is not recommended for students in this department.

I want to take a probability course that can help me with future cs classes and my academic life in general. (I don't know how relevant this is but I want to take CS189 before graduating too)

I have only taken CS70 and CS170 so far and I have been hearing from a lot of people about EE126, Stats 134, Stats140 and Stats 154. For people who have taken these courses could you please explain the differences and which would be more useful in what sense. I can only take one of these classes so I would really appreciate any help!
history.subject: Next probability course?
